GameDBLocalizedString.Text: Chlamydia
Chlamydia is passed on through unprotected sex and is particularly common in sexually active teenagers and young adults.
Gonorrhoea
Gonorrhoea is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by bacteria called Neisseria gonorrhoeae or gonococcus. It used to be known as "the clap".
Pubic Lice
Pubic lice (sometimes called crabs) are tiny insects that live on coarse human body hair, such as pubic hair.
Syphilis
Syphilis is a bacterial infection that's usually caught by having sex with someone who's infected.
HIV
Human Immunodeficiency Virus damages the cells in the immune system and weakens the ability to fight everyday infections and disease.
Genital herpes
Genital herpes is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) passed on through vaginal, anal and oral sex.
Scabies
Scabies is an itchy skin condition caused by tiny parasites. It’s passed through skin-to-skin contact, usually during sex.
HPV
HPV is the name of a very common group of viruses. They do not cause any problems in most people, but some types can cause genital warts or cancer.
Molluscum contagiosum
Molluscum contagiosum is an infection that causes small bumps on the skin. It can be contracted through touching infected skin, including during sex.
Trichomoniasis
Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by a tiny parasite called Trichomonas vaginalis (TV).
Bacterial vaginosis
Bacterial vaginosis (BV) is an imbalance of bacteria in the vagina and a common cause of unusual vaginal discharge.
Cervicitis
Cervicitis is an inflammation of the cervix commonly caused by sexually transmitted infections.
Mycoplasma genitalium
Mycoplasma genitalium is also known as MG or Mgen. It's a sexually transmitted bacterium that infects the urinary and genital tracts of men and women.
Mycoplasma genitalium
Mycoplasma genitalium is also known as MG or Mgen. It's a sexually transmitted bacterium that infects the urinary and genital tracts of men and women.
PrEP
The patient is eligable for PrEP, a drug used to prevent HIV.
Urethritis
Urethritis is inflammation of the urethra, usually caused by an infection.
Erectile dysfunction
Erectile dysfunction (ED) is the inability to get or keep an erection firm enough to have sexual intercourse.
Hyperspermia
Hyperspermia is a condition in which a male has an abnormally large ejaculate (or semen) volume, and is generally defined in humans when the ejaculate is above 5.5 ml.
Hypospermia
Hypospermia is a condition in which a male has an unusually low ejaculate (or semen) volume, less than 1.5 mL.
Epididymitis
Epididymitis is where a tube (the epididymis) at the back of the testicles becomes swollen and painful.
Balanitis
Balanitis is a skin irritation on the head of the penis that can affect men and boys.
Prostatitis
Prostatitis is inflammation (swelling) of the prostate gland.
Lymphogranuloma venereum

Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) is a sexually transmitted infection caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1–L3, often presenting as a painless ulcer followed by secondary inguinal lymphadenitis/proctitis, requiring early antibiotic treatment and partner tracing.
Granuloma inguinale

Granuloma inguinale (also known as donovanosis) is a chronic, progressive ulcerative disease of the external genitalia caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, characterized by painless, beefy-red ulcers, and treated with macrolides or tetracyclines.
Vulvovaginal candidiasis

Vulvovaginal candidiasis is an inflammation of the vulva and vagina caused by an overgrowth of Candida, with common symptoms being vulvar itching and cottage cheese-like discharge. Diagnosis relies on microscopy or culture, and treatment is with topical or oral azole antifungals.
Acne vulgaris

Acne is a chronic inflammatory disease of the pilosebaceous units, presenting as comedones, papules, pustules, and nodules, driven by factors like androgens, increased sebum, and abnormal follicular keratinization.
Rosacea

Rosacea is a chronic facial inflammatory skin disease characterized by persistent erythema, flushing, telangiectasias, and papulopustules, which can be triggered by spicy food, alcohol, heat, and sun exposure.
Eczema

Eczema (atopic dermatitis, etc.) is a relapsing-remitting inflammatory skin disease, mainly presenting with pruritus, dryness, and eczematous lesions. Impaired skin barrier function is a key mechanism.
Urticaria

Urticaria is a group of skin and mucous membrane allergic reactions presenting as wheals/angioedema, which can be induced by immune or non-immune factors. Individual wheals usually resolve in less than 24 hours.
Psoriasis
Psoriasis is an immune-mediated chronic keratinizing skin disease, typically with well-demarcated erythematous scaly plaques, and can affect nails and joints (psoriatic arthritis).
Vitiligo
Vitiligo is an acquired autoimmune depigmenting disorder, presenting as well-defined milky-white macules/patches, and may be associated with other autoimmune diseases.
Tinea corporis
Tinea corporis is a superficial fungal infection of the body caused by dermatophytes, often presenting as annular erythematous patches with an active, raised border and central clearing.
Tinea cruris
Tinea cruris is a dermatophyte infection of the inguinal folds, with significant itching and an active border, often spread from tinea pedis to the groin.
Tinea capitis
Tinea capitis is a dermatophyte infection of the scalp and hair, common in children, seen as black dot broken hairs or a kerion (pustular abscess), requiring systemic antifungal treatment.
Pityriasis versicolor

Pityriasis versicolor (tinea versicolor) is caused by the proliferation of Malassezia, appearing as hypopigmented or hyperpigmented patches with fine, bran-like scales. KOH prep shows a "spaghetti and meatballs" pattern.
Verruca vulgaris (Common Wart)
Common warts are hyperkeratotic growths caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) infection, common on hands and feet. Paring reveals thrombosed capillary black dots.
Verruca plana (Flat Wart)
Flat warts are small, flat papules caused by HPV, commonly found on the face and extensor surfaces of the limbs, often in groups.
Impetigo
Impetigo is a contagious superficial bacterial skin infection, often with honey-colored crusts, usually caused by Staphylococcus aureus or Group A Streptococcus.
Pityriasis rosea
Pityriasis rosea is a self-limiting rose-colored papulosquamous skin eruption, often starting with a "herald patch," followed by a 'Christmas tree' distribution along the ribs.
Alopecia areata
Alopecia areata is an autoimmune disease causing non-scarring patchy hair loss, with "exclamation mark" hairs at the periphery. The course is often relapsing-remitting.
Lichen planus
Lichen planus is an inflammatory skin disease affecting the skin, mucous membranes, and nails, with typical violaceous, polygonal, planar papules, and Wickham's striae on the surface.
Dermatitis herpetiformis

Dermatitis herpetiformis is an intensely pruritic herpetiform rash associated with celiac disease. Direct immunofluorescence shows granular IgA deposits in the dermal papillae, responding well to a gluten-free diet and dapsone.
Melasma

Melasma is an acquired symmetric brownish hyperpigmentation on the face, often related to UV exposure, pregnancy/hormones, and genetic predisposition. A Wood's lamp can help determine if it is epidermal or dermal.
Hidradenitis suppurativa

Hidradenitis suppurativa is a chronic, recurrent inflammatory disease of the apocrine gland-bearing areas like the axillae and groin, characterized by painful nodules/abscesses and sinus tract scarring.
